title: Gravitation
subject: Physics
learning_objectives: Learn about acceleration due to gravity

sections.title: Universal Law of Gravitation
sections.content:
**Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation:** Every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force that is:
• Directly proportional to the product of their masses
• Inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them

**Formula:** F = G × (m₁ × m₂) / r²

Where:
• F = Gravitational force
• G = Gravitational constant (6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ Nm²/kg²)
• m₁, m₂ = Masses of the objects
• r = Distance between the centers of the objects

sections.title: Acceleration Due to Gravity (g)
sections.content:
**Acceleration due to gravity (g)** is the acceleration experienced by an object falling freely under gravity.

**Value:** g = 9.8 m/s² (approximately 10 m/s²)

**Formula:** g = G × M / R²

Where:
• M = Mass of Earth
• R = Radius of Earth

**Note:** The value of g varies:
• At poles: g is maximum
• At equator: g is minimum
• With altitude: g decreases
• With depth: g decreases

sections.title: Mass vs Weight
sections.content:
**Mass:**
• Amount of matter in an object
• Scalar quantity
• Measured in kilograms (kg)
• Remains constant everywhere

**Weight:**
• Gravitational force on an object
• Vector quantity
• Measured in Newtons (N)
• Changes with location

**Formula:** Weight = Mass × g
W = m × g

**Example:** A 60 kg person:
• On Earth: W = 60 × 9.8 = 588 N
• On Moon: W = 60 × 1.6 = 96 N

sections.title: Free Fall
sections.content:
**Free fall** is the motion of an object falling under the influence of gravity alone, with no air resistance.

**Characteristics:**
• All objects fall with the same acceleration (g)
• Mass does not affect the rate of fall
• In vacuum, a feather and stone fall together

**Equations of Motion for Free Fall:**
• v = u + gt
• h = ut + ½gt²
• v² = u² + 2gh

Where h is height and g is taken as positive for falling objects.

key_points: Gravitational force is proportional to masses and inversely proportional to distance squared
Acceleration due to gravity (g) ≈ 9.8 m/s² on Earth's surface
Mass is constant; weight changes with gravity
In free fall, all objects fall with the same acceleration

quiz_questions.question: What is the value of acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
quiz_questions.explanation: The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 m/s².

quiz_questions.question: What is the weight of a 10 kg object on Earth? (g = 10 m/s²)
If you go to the Moon, what happens to your mass and weight?
quiz_questions.explanation: Mass remains constant everywhere. Weight decreases on Moon because g is less there.

quiz_questions.question: In a vacuum, which falls faster - a feather or a stone?
options: Both fall at the same rate
quiz_questions.explanation: In a vacuum (no air resistance), all objects fall at the same rate regardless of mass.
